summary: This is an internal NSD (National Security Division) Daily News Brief dated December 11, 2017, summarizing news articles from the Attorney General's News Briefing. It covers topics including the Russia investigation, FBI personnel changes, congressional probes, and various national security issues. Notably, it includes a brief mention of an attempt by Fusion GPS to link Donald Trump to convicted pedophile Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeff Sessions
persons.context: Subject of an FBI email regarding disclosure of foreign contacts for his security clearance; held a drug policy roundtable focusing on marijuana.

persons.name: Peter Strzok
persons.context: Removed from special counsel Robert Mueller's team after allegedly sending anti-Trump, pro-Clinton text messages; accused by Republicans of bias.

persons.name: Robert Mueller
persons.context: Leading the Russia investigation; his team's integrity is questioned by Republicans following revelations about Strzok and Andrew Weissman.

persons.name: Andrew Weissman
persons.context: Member of Mueller's team who sent an email praising Sally Yates for defying Trump's travel ban, cited as evidence of anti-Trump bias.

persons.name: Sally Yates
persons.context: Praised in an email by Andrew Weissman for defying President Trump's travel ban executive order.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Allies use revelations about Mueller team members to push back against Russia investigation; discussed in context of obstruction allegations and his son's testimony.

persons.name: James Comey
persons.context: Fired by President Trump; his decisions regarding the Clinton and Trump investigations are discussed; cited by Judge Jeanine Pirro as part of a group needing 'cleansing'.

persons.name: Andrew McCabe
persons.context: Singled out by Judge Jeanine Pirro as part of a group allegedly dedicated to protecting Hillary Clinton or destroying President Trump.

persons.name: Bruce Ohr
persons.context: Singled out by Judge Jeanine Pirro as part of a group allegedly dedicated to protecting Hillary Clinton or destroying President Trump.

persons.name: Adam Schiff
persons.context: Criticized Republicans for trying to discredit Mueller and institutions; stated evidence of Trump campaign-Russia coordination is 'pretty damning'.

persons.name: David Archey
persons.context: Joined Mueller's team after Strzok's removal; described as a 'utility man' within the FBI; was involved in launching the probe into Hillary Clinton's email server.

persons.name: Chuck Grassley
persons.context: Accused by Democrats of stonewalling investigations into the Trump administration; fired back at Democrats for having a 'double standard'.

persons.name: Sheldon Whitehouse
persons.context: Questioned whether a Republican senator was 'nudged' by the White House to probe Fusion GPS, diverting from Russia/obstruction investigations.

persons.name: Christopher Wray
persons.context: Testified before the House Judiciary Committee; criticized by the Wall Street Journal for stonewalling, but praised by Joe Scarborough for defending the FBI's integrity.

persons.name: Jim Jordan
persons.context: Suggested during an exchange with FBI Director Wray that Peter Strzok used the Clinton-funded dossier to get a warrant to spy on the Trump campaign.

persons.name: Jim Himes
persons.context: Stated the House Intelligence Committee is considering subpoenaing Donald Trump Jr. to get more answers about his Trump Tower meeting.

persons.name: Donald Trump Jr.
persons.context: Interviewed by the House Intelligence Committee about the 2016 Trump Tower meeting with a Russian lawyer; considered using attorney-client privilege to avoid describing conversations with his father.

persons.name: Peter King
persons.context: Stated that based on Trump Jr.'s interview, there was no indication of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia.

persons.name: George Papadopoulos
persons.context: Pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI about efforts to connect the Trump campaign with Russian officials; had high-level access to Greek officials.

persons.name: Glenn Simpson
persons.context: Reportedly pitched stories to reporters attempting to link President Trump to convicted pedophile Jeffrey Epstein and a special email server between Trump Tower and a Russian bank.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned in a report that Fusion GPS attempted to pitch a story linking President Trump to him, noting he was once buddies with former President Bill Clinton.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Mentioned as having been 'buddies' with convicted pedophile Jeffrey Epstein in the context of a story pitch by Fusion GPS.

persons.name: Jeanine Pirro
persons.context: Called for a 'cleansing' at the FBI and DOJ, singling out several officials including Mueller, Comey, Strzok, McCabe, and Ohr.

persons.name: Joe Scarborough
persons.context: Praised FBI Director Christopher Wray for defending the honor and integrity of FBI professionals during his testimony.

persons.name: Eliana Johnson
persons.context: Commented on CNN that Donald Trump Jr.'s claim of attorney-client privilege seemed 'ridiculous on its face' and a 'desperate measure'.

connections.description: Strzok was an investigator on special counsel Robert Mueller's team until he was removed.
Weissman is a prosecutor and member of Mueller's special counsel team.
Father and son; the document discusses Trump Jr.'s testimony and potential conversations with his father about the Trump Tower meeting.
Fusion GPS founder Glenn Simpson reportedly pitched a story to reporters attempting to link Donald Trump to convicted pedophile Jeffrey Epstein.
The document states Epstein was 'once buddies with former President Bill Clinton'.
Papadopoulos was a foreign policy adviser to the Trump presidential campaign.
Schiff, a Democrat, is critical of President Trump and his campaign's alleged coordination with Russia.
Rep. Jim Jordan suggested Strzok used the Clinton-funded dossier to obtain a surveillance warrant on the Trump campaign.
Pirro singled out Comey as part of a group she said needed to be 'cleansed' from the FBI and DOJ.

events.title: NSD Daily News Brief
events.description: Internal National Security Division news briefing summarizing media reports on the Russia investigation, FBI, congressional probes, and national security.

events.title: FBI Email on Sessions Contacts
events.description: An FBI email from March indicated Attorney General Jeff Sessions was not required to disclose foreign contacts from official government business on his security clearance form.

events.title: Sessions Drug Policy Roundtable
events.description: Attorney General Jeff Sessions held a drug policy roundtable at the Justice Department focusing on marijuana policy, calling it 'not a healthy substance'.

events.title: Revelations on Mueller Team Bias
events.description: Reports surface that Peter Strzok was demoted from Mueller's team for anti-Trump texts, and Andrew Weissman praised Sally Yates, giving Trump allies ammunition against the Russia probe.

events.title: Trump Jr. House Intelligence Committee Interview
events.description: Donald Trump Jr. testified before the House Intelligence Committee about the 2016 Trump Tower meeting with a Russian lawyer; he attempted to invoke attorney-client privilege regarding conversations with his father.

events.title: Papadopoulos Guilty Plea
events.description: George Papadopoulos pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI about his efforts to connect the Trump campaign with Russian officials.

events.title: Epstein Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty in 2008 to soliciting sex from an underage girl.

keyFacts: An internal NSD news brief from December 11, 2017, summarizes media reports, including one that Fusion GPS attempted to pitch a story linking Donald Trump to convicted pedophile Jeffrey Epstein.

The brief details significant developments in the Russia investigation, including the removal of FBI agent Peter Strzok from Mueller's team over anti-Trump texts and the testimony of Donald Trump Jr. before the House Intelligence Committee.
It reports on an FBI email from March 2017 stating Attorney General Jeff Sessions was not required to disclose official foreign contacts on his security clearance form.
The document captures intense partisan conflict over the Mueller probe, with Republicans alleging bias and Democrats like Adam Schiff accusing them of trying to discredit institutions.
It mentions that George Papadopoulos, who pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI, had high-level access to Greek government officials sympathetic to Russia.
